content: The Act may be cited as the "Ensuring Access to Primary Care for Women & Children Act". Congress finds that Medicaid is crucial for providing coverage to millions of working families, including pregnant women, children, individuals with disabilities, and other low-income individuals. In 2014, the program covered 69 million Americans, with the number expected to grow due to the Affordable Care Act expanding eligibility. If all states expand their Medicaid programs, an estimated 7 million women aged 18 to 64 would gain coverage. Congress recognized the importance of Medicaid in providing coverage to millions of working families. Medicaid pays significantly less than Medicare for primary care services in most states. To address low provider participation, Congress increased Medicaid payments for certain services to match Medicare rates in 2013 and 2014. Higher Medicaid payment rates have improved appointment availability for enrollees, as demand for primary care services is expected to rise with more Americans becoming insured. Medicaid has increased appointment availability for enrollees, especially women who regularly see OB/GYN physicians. Nurse practitioners and other health professionals play a crucial role in delivering primary care services, and applying Medicare's rates for them can improve Medicaid participation and access to care in underserved areas. Increasing access to primary care, particularly in underserved areas, is facilitated by the enhanced Medicaid reimbursement rate for providers. Additionally, the inclusion of nurse practitioners, physician assistants, certified nurse-midwives, and OB/GYN physicians in primary care settings improves access to essential healthcare services for women and children nationwide. Renewal of Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid and inclusion of additional providers. Renewal of Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid, ensuring payment at a rate not less than 100 percent of the rate under Medicare Part B for primary care services. The text chunk discusses the renewal of Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid, ensuring payment at a rate not less than 100 percent of the rate under Medicare Part B for primary care services provided by specific physicians. The text chunk outlines the eligibility criteria for physicians to receive Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid, including self-attestation of board certification in specific specialties or being an advanced practice clinician. The eligibility criteria for physicians to receive Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid include working under the supervision of a physician, nurse practitioner, physician assistant, or certified nurse-midwife in accordance with State law. The Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid includes reimbursement for services provided by nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and certified nurse-midwives working in accordance with State law at rural health clinics, Federally qualified health centers, or other health clinics. The Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid includes reimbursement for services provided by nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and certified nurse-midwives working in accordance with State law. The Medicare payment rate floor for primary care services under Medicaid includes reimbursement for nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and certified nurse-midwives working in accordance with State law to ensure fair payment for their services. The Ensuring Access to Primary Care for Women & Children Act amends the Social Security Act to provide additional periods for Medicaid reimbursement for primary care services under Medicare. The Women & Children Act amends the Social Security Act to improve targeting of primary care and ensure payment by managed care entities. The Act includes provisions for payments to providers for primary care services and requires documentation to be provided to the State and the Secretary upon request. The Women & Children Act amends the Social Security Act to improve primary care targeting and payment by managed care entities. It requires documentation of payment arrangements to ensure compliance with regulations. A conforming amendment is made to Section 1932(f) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 4. IMPROVING QUALITY AND VALUE FOR MEDICAID BENEFICIARIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on the use of alternative payment models in State Medicaid programs. Funding for the development of quality measures in the Social Security Act is amended, and quality measures specific to adult individuals with disabilities are being developed. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, along with the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, will develop adult health quality measures specific to individuals with disabilities for the Medicaid Quality Measurement Program. Priority will be given to assessing the impact of existing programs and new service delivery innovations on these individuals.
